I want to close with a segment
of my book where I describe

3340.text:
some of the things that he did
in which he was, as I put it,

3345.text:
the Poet Laureate as eco-warrior.
So I’m gonna read for five

3351.text:
minutes now, and then there
will be time for questions.

3354.text:
On the fourth of June, 1987, just
over a week before the general

3359.text:
election in which Margaret Thatcher
coasted to her third successive

3362.text:
term as prime minister, Ted
Hughes published what he called

3366.text:
an ecological dialogue in the
Times newspaper. It was headed,

3371.text:
“First Things First,” and it was
subtitled, “An election duet

3376.text:
performed in the womb by fetal
twins.” It blamed man’s headlong

3382.text:
obsession with economic growth, and
more particularly, the policies

3387.text:
of Western governments, and the
regulations of European economic

3390.text:
community for a mountain of wasted
butter, for contaminated tapwater,

3396.text:
leukemia brought on by pesticides
sprayed on grain fields,

3400.text:
and even the phenomenon of cot death.
The price of increasing the

3405.text:
gross national product, he argued,
was leafless trees, rivers

3409.text:
without fish, and human beings
suffering from pre-senile dementia.

3415.text:
The poem begins in loose iambic
pentameter, and ends in brisk,

3419.text:
rhyming trimeter, but it contains
in the middle the two longest, and

3423.text:
perhaps least poetic lines of
verse that Hughes ever wrote, but

3427.text:
they are interestingly polemical.
This is like Walt Whitman on

3431.text:
overdrive, these two lines that I’m
about to read: “And if the cost

3435.text:
of annual expansion of the world
chemical industry taken as a

3438.text:
whole over the last two decades
is a 40 percent drop in the sperm

3441.text:
count of all human males, nor can
God alone help the ozone layer or

3446.text:
the ovum, then let what can’t be
sold to your brother and sister

3451.text:
be released on the third world,
and let it return by air and sea

3456.text:
to drip down the back of your own
throat at night.” He explained

3462.text:
to a fellow poet that pollution
was the great theme of the age.

3467.text:
He had noticed, judging children’s
poetry competitions, which he

3469.text:
often did, it was something that
even 6 and 7 year olds were

3473.text:
worried about. The poem, he explained,
was inspired by his reading

3477.text:
of a book called the Poisoned Womb:
Human Reproduction in a Polluted

3481.text:
World, by a biologist called John
Elkington, who was something

3487.text:
of a preacher of eco-apocalypse.
He speculated that toxins were

3492.text:
causing a massive reduction in
human fertility. Hughes was

3497.text:
particularly troubled by the
evidence of fish changing gender

3502.text:
as a result of pollution. He did
not have any faith in Margaret

3508.text:
Thatcher’s willingness to address
the question; for one thing, her

3512.text:
husband, Dennis, was involved in
the waste disposal trade, and for

3516.text:
another, she was the sort of woman
upon whom nothing could put

3519.text:
the frighteners--she resembled an
army commander who believed he

3524.text:
could afford a casualty rate of 25 percent.
Her intransigence was

3529.text:
ironic, since she had an Oxford
degree in chemistry, but perhaps,

3534.text:
he said, it was not surprising. As
prime minister, she would listen

3537.text:
only to professional consultants
with vested interest. Besides,

3542.text:
when she had been a practicing chemist
before becoming a politician,

3546.text:
her job had merely been to
research the maximum number of

3550.text:
bubbles that can be pumped into
ice cream before it disillusions

3553.text:
the customers, a fact about Mrs.
Thatcher I didn’t know before

3557.text:
discovering it from Ted Hughes.
Ted at this time was worried by

3561.text:
bubbles of another kind. One of his
fishing friends had lived in a

3564.text:
house on the river X had observed a
white foam boiling up on the weir

3569.text:
where he fished; there was a sewage
works a little way upstream.

3573.text:
He would eventually bring another
civil case against the water

3576.text:
authority, and Ted offered his
usual support, for a headline

3580.text:
in the local newspaper read, “Top
Poet in Water Fight.” Inspired

3586.text:
by Ted, his fishing friend and his
lawyer dramatically invoked the

3591.text:
rights enshrined in the magna carta.
The judge, perhaps getting

3596.text:
into the poetic spirit of things,
compared the relevant stretch

3599.text:
of river to the face of a beautiful
woman scarred by disease, a

3605.text:
metaphor that Ted would like, and
against expectation, the fisherman

3609.text:
won their case. Ted Hughes told the
press that this was a historic

3613.text:
victory because it had reactivated
the power of the common

3616.text:
law in this terrific issue of water
quality and rivers. And then,

3621.text:
I think, very nobly, instead of
seeking damages, his fishing

3624.text:
friend asked the water authority
to contribute to the research of

3629.text:
the institute of freshwater ecology
into the polluting effects

3633.text:
of detergents into the X, and that
established a connection between

3638.text:
Ted Hughes and the ecotoxicologist,
John Sumpter, who was working

3643.text:
on that phenomenon how endocrine
disruptors were causing male

3647.text:
fish to change gender. Well, that
ecological dialogue during the

3652.text:
1987 election campaign, and the
court case against the south west

3657.text:
water, are just two of the many
instances in which Hughes used

3661.text:
his public profile as Poet
Laureate to address environmental

3665.text:
concerns. Whether it was ammonia
in the river Torridge, a proposal

3669.text:
to establish a Tarka the Otter
trail that risked disrupting the

3673.text:
fragile ecosystem of the riverbank,
an amusement park beside a

3677.text:
river in his native Yorkshire, or
an international campaign to save

3681.text:
the black rhinoceros, he was
always ready to pen a protest. He

3684.text:
always made a clear that his
concern for the natural world was

3688.text:
also concern for the humankind.
He did so most forcefully in an

3693.text:
interview on the occasion of the
publication of his most overt

3697.text:
ecological children's fable, the
Iron Woman, a sequel to the Iron

3702.text:
Man. There, he said that most people
tend to defend or rationalize

3707.text:
the pollution of water. The
general assumption was that

3710.text:
environmentalists were merely defending
fish, insects, or flowers. How

3716.text:
often is this said about
environmentalists in the states today? I

3723.text:
was sitting next to a businessman
on my flight from Texas into

3728.text:
Arizona, who said to me, “We can’t
do anything in this country

3733.text:
because we have a lame, dark
president who even believes in the

3735.text:
rights of centipedes,” and I kind
of wanted to say to him that Ted

3740.text:
Hughes would have had some interesting
thing to say about the rights

3742.text:
of centipedes. Hughes’ point here
is that to dismiss environmentalism

3748.text:
as merely protecting fish, insects,
or flowers misses the point

3752.text:
that, as he puts it, “The
effects on otters and so on are

3756.text:
indicators of what is happening
to us.The issue is not so much to

3761.text:
look after the birds and bees, as
to ferry human beings through the

3767.text:
next century.” The danger, he
writes, “is multiplied through each

3771.text:
generation. We don't really
know what bomb has already been

3775.text:
planted in the human system.” So
with the cold war at an end, the

3781.text:
old image of the fear of nuclear
annihilation was translated into

3789.text:
the fear of global ecocide--such
was the life of the Poet Laureate

3795.text:
as eco-warrior. He always enjoyed
describing his environmental

3800.text:
discoveries and interventions
in lengthy letters to his son,

3805.text:
Nicholas, his beloved son, who
studied Biology at Oxford, and went

3812.text:
to become an extremely distinguished
professor of Freshwater

3817.text:
Ecology at the University of
Fairbanks in Alaska. Ted Hughes was

3823.text:
also very good at providing long
distance paternal advice to his

3827.text:
son Nich. When Nich broke up with
his longterm girlfriend, Ted

3831.text:
comforted him with a story of his
own life, “oscillating,” as he

3837.text:
put it, “between fierce relationships
that become tunnel traps and

3842.text:
sudden escapes into wide freedom,
when the whole world seems to be

3847.text:
just there in the taking. It’s a
letter of extraordinary beauty,

3851.text:
wisdom, and tenderness which you
can find in the selected letters

3853.text:
of Ted Hughes, which tells of
the inner child within us,

3857.text:
going back to the figure of the
child in the Iron Man, and the

3860.text:
paradox as Hughes puts it, "That the
only time that most people feel

3865.text:
alive is when they’re suffering.
When something overwhelms their

3869.text:
ordinary, careful armor, and a
naked child is flung out into the

3875.text:
world. There is a key there to the
source of the cathartic power

3881.text:
of poetry. That’s why the things
that are worse to undergo are

3886.text:
best to remember,” Hughes writes.
And then he concludes, and I

3892.text:
think this is the moment where his
ecological consciousness merges

3895.text:
with his human compassion. “This,”
he says, “Is how we measure

3902.text:
our real respect to people. By
the degree of feeling they can

3907.text:
register, the voltage of life they
can carry, and tolerate, and

3913.text:
enjoy.” And it seems to me that the
greatness of Hughes as a thinker

3917.text:
and as a poet is precisely in
the degree of feeling, both for

3921.text:
humans but also for the planet, the
voltage of life that he carries

3928.text:
in his work. He then says, in a
typically self-deprecating way,

3933.text:
“End of sermon. As Buddhist says,
‘Live like a mighty river."
